title: Yasuharu Sorimachi
text:
is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>. 
Club career.
Sorimachi was educated at and played for <a href="Shimizu%20Higashi%20High%20School">Shimizu Higashi High School</a> and <a href="Keio%20University">Keio University</a>. At the high school, he won the national high school championship with his teammates <a href="Shigeo%20Sawairi">Shigeo Sawairi</a> and <a href="Tatsuya%20Mochizuki">Tatsuya Mochizuki</a>.
Sorimachi began his senior career with <a href="Japan%20Soccer%20League">Japan Soccer League</a> side <a href="Yokohama%20Fl%C3%BCgels">All Nippon Airways</a> in 1987. He helped All Nippon Airways gain promotion to the top flight in 1988. When Japan's first-ever professional league <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a> started in 1992, All Nippon Airways was transformed to <a href="Yokohama%20Fl%C3%BCgels">Yokohama Flügels</a> for whom he continued to play. While at Flügels, he won the <a href="Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> in <a href="1993%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1993</a>. He moved to <a href="Shonan%20Bellmare">Bellmare Hiratsuka</a> (later "Shonan Bellmare") in 1994. He helped the club to win the Emperor's Cup in <a href="1994%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1994</a>, and the <a href="Asian%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">Asian Cup Winners' Cup</a> in <a href="1995%20Asian%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">1995</a>.
National team career.
Sorimachi was capped 4 times for the <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japanese national team</a> between 1990 and 1991. His first international appearance came on July 27, 1990 in a friendly against <a href="South%20Korea%20national%20football%20team">South Korea</a>. He also played at <a href="Football%20at%20the%201990%20Asian%20Games">1990 Asian Games</a>.
Coaching career.
After retirement, in 2001, Sorimachi signed with <a href="J2%20League">J2 League</a> club <a href="Albirex%20Niigata">Albirex Niigata</a> and became a manager. In 2003, the club won the champions and was promoted to <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a>. He resigned end of 2005 season. In July 2006, he became a manager for <a href="Japan%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Japan U-23 national team</a>. He also served as assistant coach for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan football team</a> under manager <a href="Ivica%20Osim">Ivica Osim</a> and <a href="Takeshi%20Okada">Takeshi Okada</a> until July 2007. At <a href="Football%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Asian%20Qualifiers">2008 Summer Olympics Qualifiers</a>, he led U-23 Japan to won qualify for <a href="Football%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">2008 Summer Olympics</a>. However at 2008 Summer Olympics, Japan lost all 3 matches. In 2009, he signed with his former club <a href="Shonan%20Bellmare">Shonan Bellmare</a> and managed until 2011. In 2012, he moved to <a href="Matsumoto%20Yamaga%20FC">Matsumoto Yamaga FC</a>.
